text: People who become administrators or higher sometimes have a fixation with constantly working, and fear that not working will lead to ruin. It‚Äôs often a projection of their personal insecurities.

Yeah, they are desperate to justify their paychecks. Ironically, the obsession with constant academic instruction in elementary a) kills kids' intrinsic enjoyment of learning, and b) pushes out the foundational skills--getting along with others, fine motor skills, following directions, solving problems, gross motor skills, frustration and failure tolerance--that allow kids to excel academically are best learned organically.
THIS. A solid chunk of my kindergarten experience was the craft-type stuff from OP's PARTY!

I can't believe OP included crafts in the description of their illicit party. Crafts touch on *so many* important topics for kindergartens:

- promoting creativity and independence
- improving fine motor skills/ manipulation of small objects
- understanding responsible use/consumption of shared group resources/supplies (including turn taking and sharing)
- using office supplies including scissors, glue, and tape
- fostering interest in the arts 
- supporting and reinforcing "academic" topics, by presenting them in a different way
- providing another area where children can be and feel successful (especially for those students struggling in other academic areas, special needs students, English language learners, etc)
- being a fun and often more relaxing activity that breaks up long periods of instruction and allows kids to optimize learning 


I could go on all day.

what‚Äôs crazy is because our curriculum doesn‚Äôt allow for crafts, I didn‚Äôt realize how weak my kinders fine motor skills are.
They could barely cut or didn‚Äôt want to even try cutting any of the stuff for the crafts. I pushed them so hard and they did it. I was super proud!

Hi, I‚Äôm just popping in from r/all and *what do you mean a kindergarten curriculum doesn‚Äôt allow for crafts???* If I‚Äôm remembering kindergarten at all, we did like 99% crafts that taught letters and numbers. What are your kindergarteners expected to do all day, read out of textbooks?
Yeah. Me too. It's depressing as hell
A lot of my Kindergarten experience was crafts and I hated it.  I wanted to be learning in school, not making hand-turkeys for Thanksgiving.  You don't speak for everyone.
This is such a strange and frankly pretty rude response.
And makes passionate creative teachers leave the profession.

They also have an unreasonably narrow view of learning ‚Äî usually limited to just things that are tested in a standardized way or at least traditional academic subjects.¬†

I‚Äôve said before my college students in a technical field could have used more time practicing arts and crafts as kids because it shows up as odd weaknesses in coordination when doing mechanical tasks as adults. ¬†No youre never going to be able to measure whether that q tip skeleton was the reason a kid is able to solve a spatial problem in a lab 15 years down the road but that doesn‚Äôt mean it didn‚Äôt matter.¬†

Also, as other commenters mentioned, it‚Äôs fun stuff like parties that help kids form community and enjoy going to school.¬†
If they can't put it in a graph, they aren't interested.
The bureaucratic model of education is dehumanizing and disconnected from reality.

High school. One of the things I do in my "assessment cycle" and "data collection" is pay close attention to the kids' vibes. Sometimes less is more. Sometimes, some unstructured time is just what's needed. Sometimes, you have to push harder. That they want us to always just do it one way is actually unprofessional.

But if a kid is a disciple issue, administrators will ask if you spent time trying to connect with the students.

One day we have a speaker come in who was paid who knows how much money to tell us that we should be sharing personal experiences and learning from the students to connect with them. This approach is meant to improve mental health as well as increase effort in academics. The next week, I get a letter in my file for not being on topic and discussing topics that aren‚Äôt a part of the curriculum. 

Teachers in my district are so afraid these days of getting in trouble because of how parents and administrators feel that day.

haha the exact thing happened to me, so don't feel bad. For each student that 'you're not teaching enough', there's a student who says 'you talked to me about something important when nobody else did'. (Also, numerous research studies support the idea of better student-teacher relationships leading to higher academic success and general well-being. It is the entire first section of the literature review of my dissertation. Sharing personal stories and teaching content are both ways to support those relationships; they're not mutually exclusive, so our districts were wrong.)

Thank you!

I am lucky that my side hustle is bartending on the weekends. The kids don‚Äôt know but they get a funny surprise when they see me. It feels pretty good to hear them talk about how much they enjoyed my class and always tell stories that had nothing to do with the curriculum but always appreciated what a good role model I was and how I made their day a little enjoyable.

Shit like that is why I teach toddlers. I would hate not having any autonomy.  I have a basic curriculum outline, but I do that is about 15 minutes a day. 

I focus more on things like walking, sitting at the table to eat, saying new words, following basic directions, and learning how to cope with being upset. 

Funny thing is. I have teacher friends to tell me their 5th graders need to come re-learn some of that.
I teach high school biology and some never learned to not pick their nose in class.
More schooling has never equalled more education

I wish I worked with administrators like that. Most of the admin I have worked with considered their jobs to be sitting back and delegating their work to the people below them, then taking credit for that work.
Ya don‚Äôt change your style this sounds like a nice event !
Doing crafts is learning.

This should have been her argument. Being a bullshit artist is a skill most people don‚Äôt understand. Calmly respond with ‚Äúoh sorry the party was only for the last 20 minutes. We spent the first 40 doing SEL crafts related to Halloween though so i do understand how you could have thought it was all part of the party. Next time I will detail it more thoroughly beforehand so there isn‚Äôt a mix up!‚Äù
I wish I had an award to give to this comment. But, as it is, take my upvote.

That's all I remember doing in kindergarten? Crafts and singing songs and running around pretending to be she-ra. In senior kindergarten they found out I could read so they made me do some work but ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Very much so
If you're creative you can find a standard to connect to anything.
Absolutely yes!  Social/Emotional Learning is an easy go-to for this!
My school is one of the shitty schools that uses a scripted curriculum and were not supposed to do anything outside of it. üò≠

Then that's the crux of the matter right there. Heaven forbid if you have a kid with a great question that leads to a teachable moment. Heaven forbid if you find a better way to teach a concept than what is in the scripted curriculum. 

Scripted curricula don't require teachers of any particular knowledge or skill level. They're often instituted because of some warped concept of parity: if we don't teach kids the exact same material in the precise same way in the same span of time, then learning isn't equitable, this idiot concept says. Kids aren't widgets on an assembly line. They have varying needs, skills, abilities, and interests. 

There's another reason for instituting this curricula: it doesn't require teachers of any particular knowledge, education, or skill level. This allows districts and states to hire people who have none of those things and who will work for minimum wage. It's easy! All you have to do is read and babysit! /s

Well maybe your kids are just so amazing that you really charged through the script, in completion of course, and you, being the amazing teacher that you are, were able to keep them calm, working, and happy with your quick thinking skills to have them work on a craft to enhance their fine motor skills, supplementing your handwriting curriculum, as well as knowing that your students need extra support in these fine motor skills, so you had an amazing group of volunteers come in to assist you. 

But for real- the ‚Äòlast 30 mins‚Äô crowd doesn‚Äôt know that kindergartners are a hot mess at party time and it takes time. The people doing walk-throughs the last hour of Halloween are a bunch of jerks. The people who set your school to a scripted curriculum are out of touch. 

But the people who came into your class and experienced that marvelous time with you and your babies? You made an amazing connection with them and they saw you as a real human who cares for their precious little ones. And your babies made a core memory to take on with them in their sea of scripted awfulness for the rest of their educational life. 

Maybe your parents can do some good trouble and start some pushback on the scripted curriculum when they find out that their kids aren‚Äôt allowed to have time to not be educational robots. 

Sending big hugs from another kinder teacher. These are the worst times, but I‚Äôm glad they have you to love on them in spite of all the awful!
This is so sweet! üò≠ü©∑Thank you!
Same :(
I tell people this all the time!

Tbh bat puppets and skeletons with q tips sound like there is opportunity for something to connect to a Kinder standard or curriculum. I‚Äôd just write them down in case anyone asks how it was relevant to learningüòÇ
In kindergarten you call it fine motor, SEL, and science and move on! I teach first grade and you best believe we are doing the same thing.

We know so much about child development and we know how important play is for growing competent adults. I learned about it back in like 2002 before I ever started my path in education.

I don‚Äôt know who we need to convince that instruction in K-3 needs to be scaled back for more play, skill, and behavior development.
Even as a music educator, we are taught that one of the best applications of musical learning for ages birth through 9 is with play.

Play based learning was literally the point of kindergarten when it was invented. I don't get the heavy push back against social emotional learning when literally almost every research study done in the last thirty years makes it clear it's the most important aspect of education.

I would have been fired! My party last all day! We watched movies and I made hotdogs and gave out chips and cookies with juice. But, my admin also hosted a Halloween parade‚Ä¶ so he clearly was not worried about instruction yesterday.
My school is the opposite. Direct Instruction is supposedly a horrible thing, and everything we do should be immersive, interactive, hands-on, engaging, and fun.
For children of kindergarten age, almost everything actually should be immersive, hands-on, engaging, and fun. These are very young children, not trained scholars.
It should also not be a full day, in 1985 for me it was a half day, we had a morning group and an afternoon group.

Yes, a full day is asking far too much of a five year old. Unfortunately, we've become accustomed to the unwise practice of separating babies from their parent all day. We tolerate this unfortunate situation because our culture values the economic productivity of parents more than we value children.
Parents can't afford to pay a daycare/babysitter for half a day 5 days a week. There are a lot fewer stay at home parents than there were in 1985.

I view days before breaks and major holidays as relationship building days. Me and my students chill and I learn way more about them because we can just chat instead of having to do our respective jobs. It's a huge part of my classroom management strategy and a pillar of my pedagogy. Kids work harder for you when you can let the facade down once in a while and show them that you're a normal person.

I‚Äôm an administrator at an elementary school.  All week long we had parents coming in to do classroom crafts.  Yesterday we did an ‚Äúassembly‚Äù at the start of the day where my job was to keep the students occupied while the entire staff got into inflatable costumes so they could parade around the gym.  Then I did my own solo ‚Äúparade‚Äù and visited classrooms in my inflatable costumes.  We ended the day with the school costume parade.  

Everyone in my school works super hard every single day to help students learn.  And that doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt still try to make elementary school fun when we can.

Motivation is a neglected factor in many schools. Getting kids excited about content leads to better long-term results. Bribery and punishment are better in the short term. Most metrics only look at the short term. State tests change so often that longitudinal data and construct validity aren‚Äôt measured. 

But yeah, tie the fun to standards. Open a bag of skittles and graph the colors, slap a math standard on the board, have them describe the flavor and call it sensory detail in writing.

All I can tell you is it gets worse and worse as they progress through school. High school teacher here in a state takeover district and the pressure is relentless. They are to be driven, bell to bell, zero breaks, free time or finishing early. It‚Äôs brutal. I feel so bad for my students.
No wonder kids are anti-social weirdos now.
Kindergarteners learn through play. Your activities sounded educational to me! I'm sure you could find standards to relate everything to if necessary.

My principal did an informal observation with one of my classes yesterday. Not only was it Halloween but it was also just 4 days before grades close. I was sitting at my desk grading while the kids (very loudly üò¨) did a handout and any missing work. I have no idea how long she was even in there before I noticed her. Why would she set me up like that‚Ä¶The day before I had done a killer lesson with them. Oh well üôÉ
This is how I remember my childhood! Your students will remember it!

I'm secondary, but believe kids need more time to learn how to be kids in the early years, so they should definitely do that stuff and have more unstructured play time, too.


In high school, I'm not the fun teacher. Should they have some fun? Sure! But I don't think high schoolers need a whole blowoff day, so i give them something simple that still keeps the ball moving forward.


But I'm a bah humbug.

Secondary here too. My freshmen are always like, ‚Äúare we having a Christmas party on the last day?‚Äù I have to inform them that we are not having a party because it‚Äôs finals week and we are having a‚Ä¶..final. I do usually bring some treats during the final though.

Also secondary. Some of this makes me feel like a crazy person. I‚Äôm all for fun, but also please don‚Äôt pull my kids out of class the last 20 minutes of class for a surprise halloween fundraiser with less than a day‚Äôs notice. It‚Äôs quiz day!
Do you want kids to like school or something? Get back to work!
Celebrating a party IS instruction for k. It is teaching them social skills, etiquette, and cultural awareness.

In the age of iPad babies, isnt it instructional to teach kids to use their hands? Making crafts is absolutely instructional. We need to raise kids to be confident with their hands. One of my friends is an art educator and sometimes kids try to refuse to hold scissors or fold paper in half because they've never done anything tactile in their life. Please teach these kids arts and crafts before they become a 20 year old who refuses to do the dishes.
Honestly your colleague may be warning you but is probably being too uptight. Admins usually love to see family engagement.
You were teaching. You taught how to be at a party and act appropriately. You used fine motor skills for a craft. Etc etc.

I graduated in the 90s but still have such fond memories of class parties. On Halloween my elementary school had a costume parade through the neighborhood in the morning and then the party was in the afternoon. It was something teachers, kids, and parents really got excited about.


Sure, learning is important but you have to let young kids enjoy being kids sometimes! Little kids aren't designed to sit still and listen for hours at a time. They are only little for a small window of time. Then comes middle, high school, then college if they are able/want to go, then 40+ years of work. Missing an hour of instruction, especially at that age, isn't going to cause any damage. It's *kindergarten*, ffs. When I was in kindergarten arts and crafts *were* considered instruction.¬†

Unfortunately, it's the perception that public schools (teachers!) don't do any work. TV news stories about how far behind US students are push this idea that kids aren't doing anything in school. So admins are scared that kids will go home and tell their parents that "all we did today was have a pizza party!"

Have the party anyway and call it social-emotional learning? I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs a standard that can be applied.

Like, you‚Äôre literally teaching STEM by having students recreate the skeletal system and make bat puppets. Add in a re-enactment of echolocation and all of a sudden you‚Äôre using theater to teach biology.
When you are at work you are to be working the full 9 hours, no humanity is allowed. So say we all.
That sucks, when I was in school we had the entire day for holiday things...

I would hate having that type of micromanaging, and I want to be trusted as a professional. If school is not funm then kids will not want to be there. When they are excited about school, they are engaged!
Window Dressing for insecure administrators. Fear among the ranks. Smile and plough ahead.

That's sad. I have very fond school memories of holidays where there was absolutely no work at all. Watching a Charlie Brown Christmas with all the lights off and shades down with crockpot hot chocolate a parent made; our entire grade doing a winter holiday session where we went to a different classroom every hour and did crafts and learned about Hannukah and Kwanzaa (still never met anyone who celebrates it) and went to the school's Christmas store; A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving with turkey crafts and cornucopias. 100th Day of School events, Halloween, Mother's Day, Father's Day‚Äîthose were all no-work or half-work days. Halloween always featured an all-school costume parade around the track. Plus basically only having social studies curriculum on public holidays which always had a lot of crafts. And that was all the way up to fifth grade.

How **DARE YOU** show these **CHILDREN** what **FUN** is?!?!

Then how will they stay **CONPLACENT** when they enter the workforce?!

You, sir or ma'am, are a **MONSTER**!!!

Every year at my school my grade watched halloweentown for Halloween and had a class potluck. This year we had a new principal and she banned it because she thought it would increase behaviors and waste ‚Äòvaluable instruction time‚Äô. We would still have classes in the morning just shorter and then movie after lunch. We found it minimized behaviors in the morning when they knew fun time was coming. And guess what. This year we had so many behaviors on Halloween, more than we ever had before. Because we were trying to make them work all day with no acknowledge of the day. They got hopped up on sugar at lunch too a lot of them brought their own candy. So then they wouldn‚Äôt focus at all. 
The principal also didn‚Äôt trust us to follow her directions. She did random observations of every class to make sure we did nothing Halloween or fun.
Is this why my teacher would give us bullshit assignments about the movie as a kid? Shoutout to her

I remember having fun movies in school.  Not necessarily on holiday themes either.  Lots of crafts all the time. Snacks (not all the time) at the end of the day.  Learn things that other cultures do at the same time of the year.
You didn't "do crafts," you did very important, project-based lessons working on fine motor skills which are crucial for this age group. I see no stop in instruction here. Good for you.

In kindergarten? What? That‚Äôs literally insane. They are supposed to play and enjoy school. Are admin robots? Don‚Äôt they read scientific literature? What are they doing? Seriously. It‚Äôs Halloween. Who cares.¬†

It's crazy to read this when my corporate job had us stop multiple times throughout the day to join in on Halloween activities. We did a group trick-or-treating around different managers' offices while they handed out candies or treats. We also had our leadership group dressed up as baristas and made everyone‚Äôs coffee for the morning. Mind you, yesterday was our month-end, which is a crucial time for us to get our accounting straight for the month. A small break does not interfere with learning or even affect our ability to get the job done. Huge props to you for doing this for your students!

Just want to say that reading this you brought back some amazing memories from when I was in grade school. The holiday parties are some of my favorite memories from my childhood. Especially on holidays that my parents didn't normally celebrate or do anything for us on. I'm glad you did that for your class.

I‚Äôm 29 and still vividly remember a conversation I had with my teacher in 4th grate (Mrs. Courter) during our Halloween party. Please keep doing what you are doing. One of my favorite school memories
My kids school had zero instruction Friday. They did a school parade in the morning, and movies and parties the remainder of the day. (Fridays are early days so 8:35am - 1pm.)
I hope you get past your irritation. You did the right thing, f the admins and lead. You did good! Your kids are not jaded yet and you gave them an appropriate fun day.

I would argue that it IS learning.  Crafts are an age-appropriate learning experience and sitting through an entire movie while following the plot is something that my middle schoolers struggle with because their brains have been rotted by watching only shorts on TikTok and YouTube. Anything longer than 3-5 minutes is ‚Äútoo long‚Äù for many of them!

First, get tenure (if your state has it - if not, work long enough to be able to bullshit connections between what you‚Äôre doing and something related to the curriculum or a district initiative). Once you have tenure and/or can bullshit like a seasoned vet, then write a plan for a ‚Äúfun‚Äù day, submit that shit, and go to town. If the lesson goes well, no one will question it given the student engagement. If it doesn‚Äôt, you make up some bullshit about life skills or whatever and that it didn‚Äôt work, but that teaching is all about you learning & growing, as well. I do at least 1-2 social emotional learning (SEL) days per marking period. No one‚Äôs ever questioned it, but if they did, I‚Äôd be sure to say something about classroom building, positive environment, and establishing rapport and connections between the students and each other, as well as with me. 


If none of that works, be creative. Consider the current unit of study, think about what the kids are into, and connect the two. Those days are good for the kids and good for you since they (hopefully) involve a little less work. If you try it and you really get pushback from your school, start applying elsewhere.
We want kids to learn so the right course is to make them sit still and quiet (the opposite of what they need) and wonder why it's not working. Must take more away. /s

I'm not a teacher, but I work with kids, and both Thursday and Friday the kids were just not in a learning headspace. On Thursday afternoon I asked a kid a question about a social skills video we just watched, and he said "Tomorrow is Halloween!"

Another irritating aspect of it is that there‚Äôs now this (very reasonable) push to prepare high school students for careers in the trades rather than just college and academics. How do administrators think kids are going to develop a passion for hands-on skills, building and fixing stuff, measuring and assembling? Those interests start in kindergarten and grade school.
My kids' school does this as a whole school on occasion for school celebrations, not holidays. Then the other classes don't feel left out.¬†

My Halloween half day our school had a fundraiser boo bash, yard games for PBIS, and instead of power hour we did a BOOks event. And kids wore costumes. We all had a blast and Monday we will come back and learn. You gotta find a better place to be. It's okay to have fun at school!

In the lower grades, you need to master the fine art of arguing that EVERYTHING is learning. You are giving students an opportunity to practice fine motor skills and creativity (with crafts), and students are learning and practicing to social skills needed to navigate the setting of a party. However, YMMV depending on admin, and you gotta be prepared to back up your words!

Fellow kinder teacher here. Tell me why I was looking out my window during what was supposed to be my math centers, but instead I had them do Halloween brain breaks.. I stayed looking out my window incase admin came in, because I would‚Äôve gotten in trouble that they weren‚Äôt doing their math centers/ I didn‚Äôt have a small group pulled‚Ä¶ like these kids are tired of doing the same stuff every single day. Let them have a little fun.
You're preparing these kids for real life, where they will be worked to death for the profit of the capitalist class. Where does fun factor into my yoy shareholder gains?

Dude, I taught a literacy-based lesson on the ancient history of Halloween (ancient history SS teacher) and got a two-page email from my administrator about how it was "inappropriate" for me as a "PLC leader" to get off the pacing guide (which we are ahead of) and not sharing that lesson with my SS team (I offered, but the other two teams had an event day that we did last week). I didn't even talk about human sacrifices!!!!
Usually holiday parties are either an all yes or an all no thing in every district I‚Äôve worked in.

Doing a craft is learning. Learning to cut shapes, learning how to paste without getting glue everywhere, learning creative things is learning!

Maybe the movie was an issue? But even so - we.used to watch movies in class on days like that too - full length movies! We used to do it and we came out fine. This sounds silly. What are you gonna break up a movie into 3 parts on 3 different days just to get through a 90 minute film? 

Ridiculous and I'm sorry you have to deal with that non-sense. Maybe the policy can be changed so that "with approval" a longer party can be hosted?
Real estate

A solid chunk of my adulthood is catching up on the events I‚Äôd missed because I was too busy trying to juggle being social and school stuff. 

Like, what do you mean Superbad was a good movie?

I had a coteacher yesterday ask me to create a fun halloween activity for our 7th graders. So I used my entire plan time to create a reading comprehension escape room. After I sent it to her she decided that only students who had no missing work would get to participate. Literally every student has missing assignments or an assignment that needed to be redone. So instead of doing a fun activity, we all sat in silence doing the same thing we do everyday. 

I made a point to tell her that this is one of the reasons kids hate school as they get older.

Admin had to know if you had parents in the room. 

If they didn‚Äôt know that there were parents in your room, that is objectively 10x more offensive than giving five year olds a Halloween party

During remote learning on Halloween 2021 I was shocked to see my principal requesting access to join my kindergarten Zoom class. He stayed for 40 minutes!!! We were doing all fun Halloween activities, too!
Why ask parents? You're the teacher.
Come to my school. We worked hard M - R just so we could party like sugared up meerkats all day Friday. Plus we had a fire drill.

I teach K and yesterday we did no curriculum, all Halloween activities. Creepy carrot craft-worked on fine motor skills. Room on the broom sequencing activity and writing/drawing extension-connecting to the text and comprehension. Math was roll a pumpkin # with a dice and bracelet making with a pattern. The students had fun and didn‚Äôt even realize they were learning. What your are describing is so dumb but I‚Äôve been there and it corrodes a teachers love of the job.
Try that in HS

Much of this comes from the late 90's early 2000's charter movement (at least where I live) with the idea of tea her accountability and no longer having to deal with a school board, but rather a board of investors. There is an inherent mistranslation between the language of the business world and the "developing a functioning and solid human (i.e. teaching) world. 

The time of your employees and the customer  worth money. Our kids are worth money. Therefore the time developing them into test score maximized zombies is money. Why give a shit about a 10 year old in 8 years if you can pull your company's funding in 3?

Essentially, applying the capitalist/factory mindset to the classroom.

Don't worry, they are holding on to the last bit of control to fake power structure/hierarchy they have left. But it isn't going to last long lol. These kids benefit more from creativity, play and connection than learning what AI is already rapidly learning to do flawlessly. We are supposed to be having fun, not slaves to systems of hierarchy. The jobs of the future will be bio-ethics, human hands participating in land cultivation and resource expansion using AI algorithms. And humans managing AI who have been chosen for innately having bio-ethical morality. This is the future. My favorite teacher who made a lasting impression on me allowed us to memorize a play in spanish (a second language) and then perform it for our parents. That was the only memory I have that I wasn't afraid to perform. I was proud of myself and empowered. That experience was what school is supposed to be. Teachers who have creative freedom in how they teach, and children who get to learn by doing and participating.
We were recently told that admin and district staff were in our rooms not because we aren‚Äôt good teachers, but because they want to make us even better.
Depends on your school! Our whole school did crafts and Halloween parties throughout the whole day. I think it's great to let kids have fun and experience fun in school as well.

You guys WERE learning.¬† Rephrase things,¬† you weren't watching a movie.. the kids were learning how to pay attention during a long presentation and also learning how to handle judgment when judgment shouldn't be given
Just nod and or don‚Äôt advertise. At the end of the day the team lead is a worker on the same level as you, not your boss
This is why I ‚Äúteach‚Äù PE

The last hour is fine! You made sure all other lessons were taught beforehand. There is nothing wrong with scheduling some fun and creative activities to promote social relationships, build some fine motor skills and develop home-school partnerships. You can definitely buzzword explain it if you need to. If it was everyday then there would be issues. The students would have already been so excited for Halloween that trying to get through normal curriculum pacing would have been frustrating.

I think it comes from the fact that this job has a ‚Äúsnapshot‚Äù effect with higher ups. Unlike an office job where you can see your subordinates‚Äô work ethic, style, etc., in education it‚Äôs data or a walkthrough. Not every class has data or even the data can tell the whole story. So they rely on an observation. But‚Ä¶that snapshot had a lot of factors. Some teachers do a whole dog/pony show or are pals with admin so they get ‚ÄúHighly Effective‚Äù. Others aren‚Äôt so lucky ‚Äî one year I got dinged because admin came during the middle of an exam and didn‚Äôt ‚Äúsee much activity‚Äù. When I explained, he back peddled but the damage was done. 

He wanted to see ‚Äúproduction‚Äù. He didn‚Äôt bother noticing that students were doing an exam, working out problems, formula sheets, student-crafted study guides, etc. nope. He just wanted to check off boxes.
Part of the whole lesson plan for primary school is teaching empathy, socialization, etc. some administrators seem to forget that. There was real educational value in what you did.¬†

Because most administrators have no critical thinking skills. They can‚Äôt understand that a few hours of fun in the classroom ‚â† children being ruined for life academically. They see things in black and white terms. Most admin are failed educators at best.

I'm a parent and I think you are right on cue!!! Your instincts are great and I for one would love to have my kids taught by someone like you who makes wise decisions that support the whole child. Thank you ‚ù§Ô∏è

Not to mention, this kind of thing can be great for class bonding/climate which can make the instruction on future days be more efficient and fruitful! When everything has to cause immediate gains, we lose out on getting to use all the long term strategies and the results really suffer!

This is crazy. My kids K class did nothing instructional at all yesterday. It was party at 9am, recess 10-10:30, a 30 minute show while they ate their party snacks, then a parade, then early release before lunch. I feel like the school just expects Halloween to be chaos.
We had a party first thing because the parade was an hour after school started. Afterwards, we watched a movie, had lunch in the class while finishing the movie and played Halloween bingo. Great day!
Are your students having fun with fidelity?
I‚Äôve never been more tired of a word than fidelity and internalization. üò≠
instant reprimand for not at least attempting to teach the days topic.
My district encourages Halloween parties... Maybe fire up the resume and look for an easier going school.

It's because students aren't meeting standards. This is of course because the standards aren't developmentally appropriate but that's not relevant to admin and higher. There is a belief that if we just teach enough, students will be ready to understand things that their brain is not ready for

I‚Äôm in high school, so maybe that‚Äôs why I feel differently, but I know I find it pretty frustrating when my colleagues decide their class is going to have a ‚Äúfun day‚Äù for their classes that day because I have kids that then try to get out of my class to go hang out and have more ‚Äúfun day‚Äù in the other classroom. I‚Äôm not against doing fun things or even having breaks from lessons and whatnot, but I also think a specific policy about how much time is allotted to something like that keeps things consistent and prevents things like ‚Äúwell THAT class got to have a party and we didn‚Äôt‚Äù among parents and kids. As someone else mentioned, it seems like some activities could also have been tied into your standards and learning targets at that level, which means you could have had halloween theme all day and just did the exclusively ‚Äúparty‚Äù part the last 20-30 minutes. Not to mention learning and lessons can also be fun? Ultimately the kids are at school to learn and our job is to teach them, and from a legal/admin standpoint, schools are bound to a certain number of instructional minutes. 

In no way am I trying to say you are doing this all the time or way out of line, but not having a policy could mean too much time being used for parties rather than learning and call into question if your working hours are being used approriately.

I taught HS for over 20 years and I never once cared what other teachers were doing. I had days, being a History teacher, where we could watch a cool movie that ties into the curriculum‚Ä¶the beauty of being a teacher is to have some freedom to do what you want in the classroom and if other teachers want to have fun days, fine by me

I also do fun things in class from time to time and generally don‚Äôt care how other teachers are using their time. I feel perfectly comfortable handling classroom management and discipline in my own room. I do think it‚Äôs an issue when that freedom is abused though. When one teacher decides to have a bean bags tournament for the entire week instead of regular curriculum, and tells the kids they can come out of other classes to do it all day if they want and their teacher lets them, it starts to affect the way my students expect they can behave. 

For elementary, if one kingergarten teacher lets them party all day, and the other 2-3 don‚Äôt have a party, it does set up those other classes to be pitted against each other. In my district, if 2nd grade is going to do a halloween party, all of the 2nd grade does it, not just one teacher.

That just sounds like a discipline issue your school has if kids cut class and then go to another‚Äôs teacher‚Äôs class to eat snacks, watch a movie, listen to music, etc. But I will admit I‚Äôve never had a class bigger than 32 or 120 total students (and I hated it). If each teacher at your school has 200+ total students and class sizes of 35+ I could see how it could maybe be confusing.

You're absolutely right. It's frustrating when kids are in party mode, especially when admin frowns on it. Because of admin stance, I've told my students that we will never have a party in my class, but if they keep their grades up, I will frequently allow them to have "free time with snacks".  

Seriously, though, even high school kids need to let loose sometimes too. An occasional class period of "free time with snacks" goes a long way towards easing up on some of the stress that the daily curriculum push puts them under. As far as other teachers partying, that's not an issue unless you make it one. If students are allowed to let loose in one class, then at least they have a chance to get it out of their system before they come to yours. Yeah, it sometimes takes some additional classroom management skills to settle them, but they are perfectly capable of settling down and learning in your classroom despite what happened earlier in the day. If they don't, you use all the same classroom management strategies that you would use on any other day.

>But let these kids have SOME fun! Is that so wrong?

Is instructional time in your classroom not *some* fun? Not at all??

And from your own telling of the story, the issue is clearly not a matter of completely banning any "fun" party time. "20-30 minutes" would have been completely fine, according to you.

Obviously, closing the textbooks and going off-script isn't necessarily bad. Kids need breaks and some variety just as much as they need discipline and structure. *Some* party time is obviously good, but someone has to draw the line because time is preciously scarce. Your post is just complaining that you wanted to take away an extra hour on the curriculum without any negative feedback. Is that single anecdotal hour going to make a difference in the long long run? Probably not. But I've rarely seen teachers complaining that incoming students got *too much* curriculum instruction from their prior classrooms. The shortfalls add up, no matter how excusable they may be on a daily basis.

This kind of thing is one of the reasons I homeschooled my own children.

Also, my walkthrough was the last 45 minutes of the day the Friday before a weeklong Fall Break. I'm still afraid to read what it says.

I believe school should be only a few hours a day, especially the younger kids and the rest should be play, organized play, but that‚Äôs how you build connections/relationships and social awareness. Sitting at a desk listening to an adult literally does 0 of those things.

I think there's a tragic reality for students who rely on the school system for an academic education that we shouldn't wave away. These are students whose parents don't or can't read to them, don't have family historical and political discussions around the dinner table, don't go to museums on the weekend, don't go to robotics summer camp in the summer, whose parents don't make them watch educational programming on the TV etc. etc. Kids who don't have those things *rely* on every minute of instructional time to make the necessary and essential progress in their academic performance. Is this a cheery thought? No. But it's reality. And for these students every minute matters. 

And honestly, kids are in school 8 hours per day 170 days per year. That's actually just ~15% of their time. And is it really such a terrible thing that kids spend 15% of their really focused on essential academic growth? Like I say, for our students who *rely* on school to make academic growth every minute matters.
